The development of efficient hydrogen production technology from methanol holds significant importance for the green advancement of low-carbon marine engines. Cu-based catalysts, as the most widely used catalysts, face challenges such as facile sintering and carbon deposition, which significantly hinder the progress of hydrogen production through methanol reforming. Notably, the intricate interactions between Cu-based catalysts and CH3OH can be thoroughly analyzed at the microscopic level, providing an effective means to elucidate the pathways for catalyst modification. This work systematically investigates the adsorption characteristics of CH3OH on Cu surface grounded in density functional theory (DFT). By analyzing geometric parameters, Mulliken charges, density of states, and other relevant metrics, the bonding mechanisms and electronic arrangements among the constituent atoms are elucidated. The interaction between CH3OH and the Cu surface is investigated using molecular dynamics simulations, complemented by energy barrier analysis of the key steps in methanol dissociation. The simulation results are further validated through experimental studies on methanol reforming. The results reveal that CH3OH preferentially approaches Cu surface via O atom, confirming its tendency for adsorption at the Top site of Cu surface. Furthermore, the incorporation of Zn elements through doping, alongside an optimal concentration of H2O, significantly enhances the adsorption capacity for CH3OH and promotes the dissociation of methanol, thereby improving the overall efficiency of the reaction. The observed promoting effect of adding H2O aligns well with the experimental findings related to hydrogen production from methanol. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methanol reforming Density functional theory Cu-based catalyst Adsorption characteristic Dissociation characteristic Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the rapid growth of the global transportation industry, the depletion of traditional fossil fuels has emerged as a pressing issue, accompanied by increasingly severe environmental pollution [1–4]. Therefore, it is imperative to reform the current energy infrastructure and actively explore novel alternative fuels [5]. Methanol, as an engine fuel, offers several advantages such as a wide ignition range and excellent lean combustion performance, which contribute to lower combustion temperatures and reduced NOx emissions. Notably, methanol fuel has been used in internal combustion engines as early as the 1930s [4]. However, there are still some serious problems in using methanol as engine fuel, such as cold start difficulty and unstable combustion [6]. For this, the methanol-hydrogen co-combustion method is proposed to enhance combustion efficiency and improve cold-start performance in methanol engines [7]. It must be noted that challenges related to the supply and utilization of hydrogen energy are significant, particularly concerning the safety of storage and transportation [8]. The volumetric energy density of hydrogen at ambient temperatures is relatively low, typically necessitating its storage at elevated pressures or via chemical adsorption. Given the rapid diffusion, inherent flammability, and potential for explosive reactions of hydrogen, leaks in inadequately ventilated environments can result in substantial damage, which currently limits its widespread application [9]. In this regard, the on-line production of hydrogen-rich gas through heat recovery presents a viable solution to the challenges [10]. Among the myriad hydrogen-rich fuels, liquid methanol emerges as the preferred choice due to its relatively mild conversion conditions (temperature and pressure) for efficient hydrogen production, convenient storage capabilities, sulfur-free hydrogen output, low toxicity, and the relative simplicity of realizing the production process [11,12]. Currently, four predominant methods for hydrogen production from methanol are widely utilized: methanol decomposition (DM), methanol steam reforming (MSR), partial oxidation of methanol (POM) and autothermal methanol reforming (ATMR) [13–18]. POM and ATMR reactions encounter notable challenges such as difficulties in temperature control and low hydrogen production rates [19], rendering them primarily confined to the laboratory research domain. Although DM reaction is considered relatively mature, high levels of CO continue to be present, and marked carbon accumulation on the catalyst is observed [20]. By contrast, MSR reaction shows milder reaction conditions, lower selectivity for carbon monoxide, and a more manageable overall process, establishing it as the predominant pathway in current methanol-to-hydrogen conversion research. To increase the methanol conversion, a diverse array of highly active and selective catalysts has been developed [21,22]. The choice of catalyst greatly influences both the conversion efficiency of methanol to hydrogen and the selectivity of the products. Three main types of catalysts are employed for hydrogen production from methanol: Cu-based catalysts, Ni-based catalysts and precious metal catalysts [23–27]. The Ni-based catalyst has a broad temperature range but delivers suboptimal hydrogen production performance. Precious metal catalysts provide excellent hydrogen production results, but the high cost prevents industrial-scale implementation. In contrast, Cu-based catalysts have attracted considerable attention due to the higher activity at low temperatures and reduced costs [19]. However, it is important to note that the stability is relatively low [28]. Several strategies have been proposed to enhance catalyst stability and activity, including the incorporation of additives and the improvement of preparation techniques. Seye et al. employed glow discharge plasma treatment on the catalysts, and it was observed that the approach effectively enhances the surface morphology, particle size distribution, and specific surface area of the nanocatalysts, thereby improving catalyst stability [29]. Furthermore, Liao et al. discovered that effective interaction between CuO and ZnO can inhibit the aggregation and growth of CuO at elevated temperatures, resulting in fine and uniform catalyst particles characterized by the highest specific surface area (SBET) and optimal reducibility [30]. The addition of Zn as an additive significantly enhances the dispersion and redox properties of the Cu phase while maintaining a lower cost [31]. Cu-based catalysts have demonstrated superior catalytic performance in methanol-to-hydrogen conversion, yet their microscopic reaction mechanisms remain unclear, necessitating atomic-level investigation into the microscopic interaction between active component and methanol molecules during catalysis. Density Functional Theory (DFT) is widely employed in computational studies within microscopic domains, owing to its ability to accurately analyze various properties, such as energy band structures, density of states, and charge density, without depending on empirical formulas [32]. The primary processes occurring on the surface of the catalyst are composed of four steps: adsorption, dissociation, recombination, and desorption. As the initial step of the catalytic reaction, adsorption notably influences the subsequent dissociation and recombination processes, making it crucial for the overall reaction efficiency [33]. Garcia-Muelas et al. investigated the methanol dehydrogenation process on the surface of Cu (111) with DFT method. They found that CH3OH achieved the lowest adsorption energy of −0.38 eV when positioned at the Top site on the Cu (111) surface. The energy barrier for methanol hydroxyl dehydrogenation was higher. Moreover, as the molecule progressively lost hydrogen atoms, the cleavage of the CH bond became increasingly favorable [34]. Ren et al. investigated the effect of H2O addition on the methanol dissociation process on the Cu (110) surface and found that methanol decomposition on H2O/Cu (110) surface was more favorable than on pure Cu (110) [35]. Most of the existing studies focus on molecular dissociation while overlooking the equally important adsorption process, which may lead to incomplete understanding of some microscopic reaction mechanisms. In conclusion, a thorough investigation into the interaction between Cu and CH3OH is essential to elucidate the microcosmic principle, thereby offering theoretical insights crucial for catalyst design. Therefore, this work employs DFT to systematically investigate the adsorption characteristics of methanol on Cu-based catalyst surfaces using Materials Studio software. The geometrical models of CH3OH adsorbed on multilayer Cu atomic surfaces and Zn-doped surfaces are constructed. The interaction between CH3OH and adsorbed surfaces is comprehensively analyzed by integrating various parameters, including adsorption energy, density of states, and charge density, and the impact of H2O on the adsorption characteristics of methanol is further investigated. In addition, the key steps of methanol dissociation on the Cu surface are briefly analyzed, and the hydrogen production characteristics of methanol on Cu-based catalyst surfaces are experimentally studied to validate the simulation results. A theoretical foundation is provided by these findings for developing efficient Cu-based catalysts for hydrogen production from methanol, while valuable guidance is offered for research on methanol decomposition and steam reforming. 2 Calculation and experimental methods 2.1 Calculation method DFT calculations in this work are performed using CASTEP module in Material Studio software. This versatile tool facilitates the accurate calculation of single-point energies, geometry optimization, first-principles dynamics, and electronic structure analysis, including the energy band structure, density of states, and differential charge density [36]. In calculating the adsorption properties of the methanol on Cu surface, the exchange-correlation energy of inter-electronic interactions is determined using the PBE form of generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [37]. The interaction between ions and valence electrons is modeled using the ultrasoft pseudopotential method, with total energy calculated via the self-consistent field (SCF) approach and a convergence tolerance of 2 × 10−6 eV/atom. The Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (BFGS) method is employed to identify the most stable structure. The total energy of the system is set to converge at 2 × 10−5 eV/atom during the geometric optimization of the selected crystal cells. The maximum values for atomic force and displacement are established at 0.05 eV/Å and 0.002 Å, respectively, while the stress deviation is kept below 0.1 GPa. Furthermore, the cutoff energy is established at 351 eV as a standard for convergence in the optimization processs [38]. The Grimme method (DFT-D2) was employed to incorporate dispersion corrections in all calculations, thereby accurately describing the long-range van der Waals interactions [39]. The transition state search is performed using the LST/QST (Local Search Transition/Quadratic Search Transition) method, with a maximum of 10 iteration steps, to identify the most stable transition state structure. The adsorption energy of methanol on Cu surfaces is investigated, focusing on the influence of Zn doping and H2O addition on adsorption behavior. It is known that the adsorption energy typically has a negative value, which indicates the strength of the adsorption capacity, a higher absolute value corresponds to a stronger adsorption effect [40]. The specific formula used for the calculation is provided below: Single methanol molecule adsorbent: (1) E a d s = E t o t a l − E s u r f a c e − E C H 3 O H Methanol-water molecule co-adsorption: (2) E a d s = E t o t a l − E s u r f a c e / H 2 O − E C H 3 O H Eads denotes the adsorption energy, Etotal is the total energy of the reaction system, E s urface is the energy of the adsorbed surface, Es urface/H2O is the energy of the model in which H2O is pre-adsorbed on the adsorbed surface, ECH3OH denotes the energy of the adsorbate CH3OH. The formula for calculating the reaction barrier (Ea ) is as follows: (3) E a = E T − E R E T and E R represent the energy of the transition state and reactant. 2.2 Model optimization and validation The initial model consists of Cu-based adsorbed surfaces along with H2O and CH3OH crystals. To mitigate the influence of interactions between periodic surfaces on the calculation results, a cell height of 15 Å is employed, and three layers of Cu atom surfaces are constructed, with the underlying Cu atoms fixed [41]. To investigate the impact of Zn addition on the adsorption characteristics, the two adjacent Cu atoms at the top of the adsorption surface were replaced with Zn atoms, thereby creating additional active sites. Pure copper and Zn-doped surfaces are defined as Model A-a and Model A-b, respectively. The cell parameters for CH3OH and H2O molecules are set to 10 Å × 10 Å × 10 Å during the construction of the cell. The optimized models, shown in Figs. 1 a-e, include blue markers representing the truncated areas in the subsequent top view images. Different adsorption sites are illustrated in Figs. 1a and 1b. The optimized CO bond length of the CH3OH molecule is found to be 1.435 Å, closely approximating the empirical value of 1.430 Å. Additionally, the optimized COH bond angle is measured at 108.99°, demonstrating remarkable proximity to the empirical value of 108.90°, thereby affirming the reliability of this structural configuration. Based on the aforementioned information, the adsorption process of CH3OH at distinct active sites on both Cu and Zn-doped surfaces are simulated. Furthermore, the adsorption characteristics of CH3OH are analyzed by calculating and comparing its adsorption energies at various positions, while the influence of H2O incorporation during the adsorption process is also considered in conjunction with model parameters such as geometric dimensions, Mulliken charges, and partial density of states. Finally, the energy barrier analysis of key steps of methanol dehydrogenation is carried out through transition state search. 2.3 Experimental method and catalysts characterization The schematic diagram of the experimental setup for investigating the hydrogen production characteristics of methanol is illustrated in Fig. 2 . The main catalytic reactions are conducted in fixed-bed reactors, allowing for precise control over reaction temperatures ranging from 220 to 400 °C. The actual temperature of the catalyst surface during the reaction can be measured in real time by a movable thermocouple installed inside the reactor. The reactor is charged with 31.4 cm3 of cylindrical Cu-Zn-Al2O3 catalyst per batch. A stream with a H2/N2 ratio of 1/4 is introduced into the reactor before the reaction, and reduction is conducted for 3 h at 220 °C. A mixture of water and methanol with a certain molar ratio is prepared in advance. N2 is employed as a carrier upon completion of this process, diluting methanol and water vapor in a 50 % proportion to facilitate the transportation into the reactor. At the reactor outlet, unreacted methanol and water are condensed by a cold trap. After that, the residual methanol is absorbed through a wash cylinder, and finally through a U-shaped tube containing anhydrous calcium chloride to absorb the remaining water. The concentration of H2 and N2 in the outlet gas of the reactor is determined by employing gas chromatography unit at the conclusion of the reaction. The quantity of unreacted methanol is estimated through calibration with H2 and N2. The equipment and chemical information used in the experiment is shown in Table 1 . The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) is defined as the ratio of the volumetric flow rate of the reactant gas to the volume of the catalyst bed. The methanol conversion (XCH3OH ) and hydrogen yield (YH2 , ml/min) are determined by utilizing the following equation: (4) X C H 3 O H = F C H 3 O H , i n − F C H 3 O H , o u t F C H 3 O H , i n × 100 % (5) Y H 2 = 3 × F C H 3 O H , in × X C H 3 O H FCH3OH ,in and FCH3OH ,out represent CH3OH import and export flow rate. The crystal structure of the samples is characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a D8 Advance diffractometer, with phase identification conducted via Jade 6 software and the JCPDS database. Textural properties, such as surface area, pore size distribution, and pore volume, are evaluated through N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms measured at −196 °C on an ASAP 2020 system. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method is employed to calculate surface areas, while pore size distribution and volume are determined using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Furthermore, the surface composition of the samples is analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi instrument. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of various atoms approaching on adsorption characteristic The adsorption configurations of CH3OH approaching the Cu surface via CH, OH, and O atoms are depicted in Fig. 3 as Model B-a, Model B-b, and Model B-c, respectively. The O atom is deflected downwards towards the Cu surface in Model B-a, while only Model B-c form chemical bond. Similar conclusions can be drawn from the methanol adsorption energy in Table 2 . The adsorption energies of CH3OH are −0.4787 eV, −0.4416 eV, and −0.6134 eV when it approaches the Cu surface with CH, OH, and O atoms, respectively. The adsorption energy is typically characterized by a negative value, with lower magnitudes indicating enhanced adsorption strength. It suggests that Model B-c exhibits the lowest adsorption energy and the most stable adsorption structure, implying a stronger tendency for CH3OH to bond with the Cu surface through the O atom [42]. Table 2 indicates that the bond lengths between Cu atoms near the adsorption sites changed when the upper Cu atoms interacted with CH3OH. Before the adsorption reaction, the Cu-Cu bond length is approximately 2.559 Å, which increased following the adsorption of CH3OH molecules. Specifically, the bond lengths in Models B-a and B-b measured 2.571 Å and 2.560 Å, respectively, showing a maximum variation of 0.012 Å. In contrast, the bond length in Model B-c increased to 2.614 Å, a rise of 0.055 Å. It suggests that the approach of CH3OH to the Cu surface via O atoms evidently alters the surface structure, further validating the previous conclusion. Additionally, the bond lengths of CH3OH remain almost unchanged after adsorption, suggesting that CH3OH structure remains largely intact on the Cu surface. Atomic Mulliken charges are summarized in Table 3 . The total electron transfer shows that the Cu surface acts as the primary source of electrons, which transfer to the CH3OH. In model B-c, charge transfer is most pronounced, with the charge change of O atom reaching 0.13. In addition, H atoms located near the adsorption surface obtain more electrons, as marked in Table 3, thereby enhancing the activity, which ultimately facilitates methanol adsorption. It is further supported by the fact that only the CH3OH in Model B-c forms a bond with the Cu surface. In summary, a more pronounced charge transfer indicates enhanced structural stability, which is characterized by the lowest adsorption energy and the most stable configuration when CH3OH is in close proximity to Cu surface via O atom. 3.2 Effect of different sites on adsorption characteristics The adsorption configurations of methanol at various adsorption sites on Cu surface, utilizing O atoms as proximity atoms, are illustrated in Fig. 4 . The Top, Bridge, and Hollow sites are designated as Model B-c, Model B-d, and Model B-e, respectively. It is noted that some degree of deviation is exhibited by all model geometries. Notably, chemical bonds are formed exclusively by CH3OH in Model B-c with Cu surface, indicating that Top site adsorption of CH3OH on Cu surface represents a more stable configuration. The adsorption energies and geometrical parameters of CH3OH at various active sites on the Cu surface are shown in Table 4 . The data presented in the table shows distinct changes in the model parameters after the adsorption reaction. Notably, increases of 0.055 Å and 0.076 Å in Cu-Cu bond lengths are recorded for Models B-c and B-d, indicating that the adsorption reaction of CH3OH significantly affects the geometric structure of the Cu surface. Regarding the adsorption energies, the negative values for various active sites indicate that CH3OH adsorption on the Cu surface is relatively stable. Specifically, Model B-c exhibits the lowest adsorption energy of −0.6134 eV, further confirmed by the distinct bonding observed only in Model B-c, as illustrated in Fig. 4. In contrast, the adsorption energies for Models B-d and B-e are recorded at relatively high values of −0.4003 eV and −0.3813 eV, implying less favorable adsorption behavior. It diverges from the previously noted variations in Cu-Cu bond lengths. The Bridge site adsorption configuration is found to demonstrate the most marked variation in bond length, potentially resulting from the direct positioning of the O atom from the CH3OH above the Cu-Cu bond, which exerts a considerable influence on its length. The Mulliken charges of various atoms in the models are presented in Table 3 for Model B-c through Model B-e. A significant charge transfer phenomenon is observed for different adsorption models. Overall, electrons are gained by the CH3OH molecule, which are subsequently transferred to the lower H atoms adjacent to the adsorbed surface. It is worth noting that in model B-c, the charge transfer at the bonding O atom is the largest, with a change of 0.13. It indicates that the Top-site adsorption model exhibits enhanced structural stability, which accounts for its comparatively lower adsorption energy on the Cu surface. Analyzing the Partial density of states (PDOS) of Cu and O atoms before and after the adsorption of Model B-c, as shown in Fig. 5 a, reveals significant peaks in the d orbitals of Cu atoms, while the peaks corresponding to Cu-s and Cu-p orbitals are comparatively weaker. After the adsorption reaction, there is minimal alteration observed in the peaks of Cu-d orbitals within the energy range of −6.0 to 10.0 eV, while subtle wave-like features emerge within the energy range of −23.0 to −6.0 eV. Furthermore, the analysis reveals that the peak intensity of the O-p orbitals near the Fermi energy level significantly diminishes after adsorption, accompanied by a notable leftward shift [43]. Fig. 5a illustrates that no resonance peaks are observed in the density of states for Cu and O atoms before the adsorption reaction occurs. In contrast, both elements exhibit numerous resonance peaks located around the energy levels of −22.4 eV, −13.4 eV, −9.4 eV, −7.4 eV, and −5.4 eV after the adsorption, which indicates the occurrence of orbital hybridization between Cu and O atoms, resulting in the formation of stable covalent bonds. Combined with the differential charge density plots for models Model B-c given in Fig. 5c (blue areas indicate electron loss and red areas indicate electron gain), the trend of upward charge transfer can be visualized more intuitively. The overlap of electron clouds between the Cu and O atoms suggests a strong interaction, implying that electron exchange takes place between the Cu surface and CH3OH, which is further corroborated by the results of Mulliken charge and density of states analyses. In summary, slight variations are observed in the adsorption characteristics of CH3OH on different active sites of Cu surface. Adsorption at the Top site reveals a stronger adsorption capacity and a more stable structure for CH3OH, compared to the Bridge and Hollow sites. 3.3 Effect of Zn elemental doping on adsorption characteristics In the field of hydrogen production from methanol, Zn is frequently utilized as an additive in catalytic systems. The impact of Zn doping on the adsorption of CH3OH on Cu surfaces is specifically analyzed in this section. The optimized models of CH3OH adsorption on Cu surface doped with Zn are illustrated in Fig. 6 . The adsorption sites, including the Cu Top site, Zn Top site, Cu-Cu Bridge site, Cu-Zn Bridge site, Zn-Zn Bridge site, and Hollow site, are designated as Model C-a to Model C-f. The geometrical parameters of the various adsorption models and corresponding adsorption energies are detailed in Table 5 . Significant changes in bond lengths surrounding the adsorption sites are observed following the adsorption reaction, indicating a robust interaction between CH3OH and Cu surface. The adsorption energy of Model C-a is −0.6670 eV, lower than the −0.6097 eV of Model C-b, which demonstrates that Cu element plays a predominant role in the CH3OH adsorption process. By comparing the data from Table 5 with Table 4, it is noted that Cu-O bond length of the Cu Top site adsorption model decreases from 2.206 Å to 2.204 Å upon the incorporation of Zn element. Additionally, the observed reduction in CH3OH adsorption energies across various active sites on Cu surface, suggests that Zn doping observably facilitates the adsorption of CH3OH on Cu surface. Mulliken charges for Models C-a to C-f are presented in Table 3. It is noted that the charge transfer in the lower atoms adjacent to the adsorption surface is relatively obvious, indicating strong adsorption activity. Furthermore, the charge of O atom in CH3OH shows considerable variations after the adsorption reaction. The exact charge of the O atom can be ranked as follows: Model C-a (−0.63) > Model C-b (−0.64) > Model C-c (−0.65) > Model C-d (−0.66) > Model C-e = Model C-f (−0.68). The ranking is in strict agreement with the sequence of adsorption energies, suggesting a close correlation between adsorption energy and the amount of charge transfer at the adsorption site. Fig. 5b illustrates the PDOS for Cu and O atoms before and after the adsorption reaction in Model C-a. Consistent with the previous section, the observation of multiple resonance peaks between Cu and O atoms after the adsorption reaction indicates orbital hybridization, which is clearly visualized in Fig. 5d through the electron cloud overlapping phenomenon. 3.4 Effect of the addition of H2O on adsorption characteristics MSR reaction is preferred over DM reaction due to its milder reaction conditions and the production of higher-purity hydrogen. Therefore, investigating the impact of H2O addition on the adsorption of CH3OH at the microscopic level is essential. Fig. 7 demonstrates the CuZn & H2O & CH3OH adsorption model with different sites, where H2O are initially adsorbed on CuZn alloy surface, followed by the adsorption of CH3OH at different active sites. The models for the Cu Top site, Zn Top site, Cu-Cu Bridge site, Cu-Zn Bridge site, Zn-Zn Bridge site, and Hollow site are labeled as Model D-a to Model D-f. Compared to the previous model with unadsorbed H2O, Model D-a shows no clear chemical bonding after optimization at the same adsorption site. However, Model D-a exhibits noticeably lower adsorption energy and an improved adsorption effect compared to Model C-a as illustrated in Table 6 . Moreover, after the adsorption reaction, H2O in the different models is deflected, with H atoms shifting toward the O atoms in CH3OH, indicating an interaction between CH3OH and H2O. Therefore, it can be concluded that the enhanced adsorption of CH3OH is due to the synergistic effect between the adsorbed surface and H2O molecules. Geometrical parameters and adsorption energies of CuZn & H2O & CH3OH models are listed in Table 6. The lowest adsorption energy of −0.8393 eV is observed for Model D-d, indicating the most favorable adsorption at the Cu-Zn Bridge site, while the highest adsorption energy of −0.7015 eV is found for Model D-a, representing the least favorable adsorption at the Cu Top site. The substantial difference compared to the adsorption model without pre-adsorption of H2O suggests that the presence of H2O dramatically influences the CH3OH adsorption effect on the CuZn alloy surface. Notable changes in the structural parameters of the model surface are observed following the adsorption of CH3OH. A comparison of the data presented in Tables 5 and 6 reveals that the adsorption energies of CH3OH at various sites on the adsorption surface are markedly reduced following the pre-adsorption of H2O, which indicates a pronounced promotional effect of H2O on the adsorption of CH3OH on Cu surfaces. Furthermore, the lengths of the Cu-O and Zn-O bonds near the adsorption sites are found to have increased compared to the Model C-a and Model C-b. It further confirms that the decrease in CH3OH adsorption energy is attributed to the synergistic effect between the adsorption surface and H2O. Mulliken charge indicates an obvious disparity in atomic charges after the adsorption reaction, characterized by a pronounced transfer of charge towards the H atoms adjacent to the adsorption surface. In comparison to the Model C, the variation in the O atom charge of CH3OH remains relatively consistent following the adsorption reaction. However, a notable charge transfer is observed within the H2O molecule, accompanied by a smaller amount of charge transfer between the adsorbed surface and H2O, which may explain the enhancement of CH3OH adsorption. The PDOS of Model D-d before and after the adsorption reaction is shown in Figs. 8 a and 8b. The peaks of Zn-s orbitals are clearly elevated after the adsorption reaction. Fig. 8a shows the absence of resonance peaks of Cu, Zn and H atoms with O atoms before the adsorption reaction. However, following the occurrence of the adsorption reaction, these atoms exhibited multiple resonance peaks positioned in close proximity to energy levels of −22.1 eV, −13.3 eV, −9.9 eV, −7.1 eV, −4.8 eV, and −3.2 eV, indicating that all of them underwent orbital hybridization with O1 atoms. In Fig. 8b, the partial peaks of the PDOS for Cu atoms show a slight reduction compared to those in Fig. 5b, with no new hybridization peaks observed within the −25.0 to −5.0 eV energy range for Cu-d orbitals (the Cu-d orbitals are not labeled due to the absence of new hybridization peaks). It indicates a reduction in charge transfer between Cu and O1 atoms, leading to a weakened adsorption effect. Simultaneously, both the Zn and H atoms undergo orbital hybridization with the O1 atom, leading to a direct observation of electron cloud overlaps as depicted in Figs. 8c and 8d by combining the differential charge density of atoms. To sum up, following the addition of H2O, the Cu-Zn Bridge position is identified as the most favorable adsorption site for CH3OH. It is found that the coadoption of H2O with the CuZn alloy surface significantly enhanced the adsorption of CH3OH. Notably, H2O will occupy active sites on the upper layers of the adsorbed surface. Highly concentration of H2O is likely to compete with CH3OH for the active sites on CuZn alloy surface, thereby reducing the adsorption efficiency of CH3OH. 3.5 Analysis of methanol dissociation characteristics To further validate the accuracy of the theoretical model and promote the integration of theoretical simulations with experimental studies, the dissociation characteristics of methanol on Cu-based catalysts were investigated. In the dissociation process, the rate-determining step (RDS) is the transition state with the highest energy in the reaction mechanism, which dominates the overall reaction rate. Currently, there is some disagreement regarding the RDS of methanol dehydrogenation on Cu-based catalyst surfaces. Some researchers propose that CH3OH* → CH3O* + H* (R1) is the RDS [44], while others suggest that CH3O* → CH2O* + H* (R2) is the RDS [38]. Therefore, the energy barriers for these two dehydrogenation steps are systematically studied. The energy barrier analysis is conducted on Cu surfaces, CuZn surfaces, and CuZn surfaces with pre-adsorbed H2O. The adsorption models of dehydrogenation species in the simulations are optimized to the most stable configurations, with detailed information on active sites and adsorption energies provided in Table S1 of the supplementary materials. The transition states for R1 and R2 are defined as TS1 and TS2, respectively. The potential energy diagram for methanol dehydrogenation is shown on Fig. 9 , with the following energy barriers: TS1: 1.8328 eV, TS2: 2.2356 eV, TS1’: 1.6695 eV, TS2’: 1.5079 eV, TS1’’: 1.3198 eV, TS2’’: 1.5443 eV. The results indicate that the RDS for methanol dehydrogenation on the Cu surface is R2, with an energy barrier of 2.2356 eV. Compared to the pure Cu surface, the activation energies for both key steps of methanol dehydrogenation on the CuZn surface are significantly reduced, and the RDS shifts to R1. It suggests that the incorporation of Zn not only enhances the adsorption of methanol on the Cu surface but also promotes the dehydrogenation process, making the reaction more favorable. On the CuZn surface with pre-adsorbed H2O, the energy barrier for R2 slightly increases (the change of energy barrier is highlighted in Fig. 9), but it has little impact on the reaction progress since R2 is no longer the RDS. In contrast, the energy barrier for R1 is significantly reduced, and the RDS shifts back to R2. It demonstrates that the presence of H2O further decreases the energy barriers for methanol dehydrogenation on Cu-based catalysts, facilitating the reaction. 3.6 Analysis of hydrogen production from methanol with Cu-based catalyst 3.6.1 Experimental comparison of hydrogen production from methanol Building upon the previous characterization of methanol adsorption, experimental investigations are conducted on Cu-based catalysts for hydrogen production from methanol. The performance and activity of the Cu-Zn-Al2O3 catalyst for methanol conversion in both DM and MSR reactions are evaluated using the experimental device shown in Fig. 2, with specific experimental results presented in Fig. 10 . The methanol conversion in the temperature range of 220–400 °C is illustrated in Fig. 10a, showing a significant increase with rising temperature for both reactions due to their strongly endothermic nature, which shifts the equilibrium in a positive direction. In addition, when the temperature exceeds 380 °C, the methanol conversion of MSR reaction decreases. It may be due to the optimal temperature range of the Cu-based catalyst being 220–300 °C. Temperature measurements of the catalyst surface show that when the reactor's set temperature is 380 °C, the lowest catalyst surface temperature is about 320 °C (Fig. 10b), which exceeds the optimal range and causes catalyst sintering and deactivation at high temperatures. At the same temperature, the methanol conversion rate of DM reaction continues to increase, which is due to its higher endothermic property, so that the catalyst surface temperature is within the applicable temperature range, and the catalyst deactivation phenomenon is not obvious, which is also verified by the subsequent temperature measurement of the catalytic bed (when the reactor temperature is set at 380 °C, the lowest value of catalyst surface temperature is around 280 °C). The actual bed temperature in the experiment, as illustrated in Fig. 10b and Fig. 10c (whereas the temperature depicted in Fig. 10a represents the set temperature of the reactor), is found to be markedly lower than the set temperature, with the lowest temperature occurring at the front part of the catalyst, which suggests that the reaction predominantly occurs in this region. Simultaneously, with the increase of temperature, the position of the lowest temperature in the reactor moves slightly forward, which confirms that the endothermic reaction tends to be higher temperature. Throughout all temperature ranges, the methanol conversion of MSR reaction is evidently higher than DM reaction. It is primarily due to the addition of water, which reacts with the CO produced during methanol cracking, resulting in the formation of CO2 and additional hydrogen. The presence of water not only serves as an additional hydrogen source, significantly enhancing hydrogen production, but also reduces the CO concentration, thereby minimizing carbon deposition on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, the previous section highlighted the distinct promotional effect of H2O on the adsorption of CH3OH on Cu-based catalysts, and the observed higher methanol conversion is consistent with the simulation results of adsorption characteristics. 3.6.2 Influencing factors of MSR reaction In MSR reaction, apart from temperature, gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) and the water/methanol ratio (W/M) are identified as crucial factors influencing the process. In order to test the effect of W/M ratio and GHSV on hydrogen production without seriously damaging the catalyst structure, 280 °C is selected as the test temperature The variations in methanol conversion and hydrogen yield with increasing GHSV are illustrated in Fig. 10d, where a decrease in methanol conversion is observed alongside an increase in hydrogen yield as GHSV rises. This behavior can be attributed to the reduced residence time of the reaction gases on the catalyst surface at higher GHSV, which makes adsorption onto the catalyst more challenging. Furthermore, the increased supply of methanol results in higher hydrogen production yield. Given the constraints of the limited experimental conditions, an increase in GHSV is expected to lead to a gradual dominance of methanol conversion, resulting in a subsequent decrease in hydrogen yield. Fig. 10e demonstrates the changes of methanol conversion and hydrogen yield under varying W/M. It is observed that methanol conversion initially rises with an increase in W/M, but a decline occurs when it exceeds 1.7. It is partially attributed to the promotion of methanol adsorption and dissociation processes by the introduction of H2O, while excessive amounts of H2O are believed to compete with CH3OH for adsorption sites, thereby affecting overall conversion efficiency. Additionally, a decrease in hydrogen yield occurs when the W/M exceeds 1.3, attributed to the reduced supply of methanol resulting from an increased W/M while maintaining a constant GHSV. While an increase in methanol conversion is achieved, it ultimately leads to a decline in the final hydrogen yield. 3.6.3 Stability tests of Cu-based catalyst To systematically evaluate the long-term and cyclic stability of the catalyst, tests are performed at a steady temperature of 300 °C, which is the upper limit of the temperature range suitable for this catalyst. The heat resistance of the catalyst is assessed by running several cycles of experiments, each time reheating it to a specified temperature. In the first cycle experiment, the methanol conversion rate reaches a stable level of approximately 84 %, which exhibited a slight improvement compared to the previous experiment conducted under identical operational conditions. After the third cycle experiment, the methanol conversion rate stabilized at approximately 77 %, reflecting an overall decline of around 7 %. It can be observed that the catalyst exhibits ideal long-term stability, which is likely due to its lower actual reaction temperature (as shown in Fig. 10b). However, the cycle stability is relatively poor, attributed to the requirement of raising the reactor temperature to 300 °C prior to each cycle experiment, followed by the introduction of the reaction feedstock. The repeated elevation of the ambient temperature may result in catalyst sintering deactivation, which is likely to adversely affect its performance. 3.7 Catalyst characterization analysis To gain deeper insights into the microstructural characteristics and chemical environment of the catalyst used in the experiments, a series of characterization analyses are conducted. As shown in Fig. 11 , the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution reveals that the catalyst sample exhibits a Type IV isotherm with a gradual increase in the adsorption branch and a relatively steep desorption branch, corresponding to a typical H3-type hysteresis loop [45]. Combined with the BET surface area information provided in Table 7 , these results indicate that the catalyst possesses a typical mesoporous structure (2–50 nm). Fig. 12 a displays the XRD patterns of the catalyst before reduction and after reforming. The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 35.5° and 38.74° correspond to the (002) and (111) crystal planes of CuO (PDF#80-1917), while those at 2θ = 35.35° and 46.74° are assigned to the (101) and (102) planes of ZnO (PDF#75-1533). Notably, the absence of distinct Al2O3 diffraction peaks (except at 2θ = 35°) suggests its amorphous and highly dispersed state in the catalyst [46]. Prior to reduction, the broad and low-intensity diffraction peaks observed in the 64°–70° range align with the characteristic peaks of CuO, ZnO, and Al2O3 in standard PDF cards, indicating small crystallite sizes and high dispersion. After reforming, these peaks exhibit increased intensity and narrowed profiles, indicating particle agglomeration and crystallite growth, which are consistent with the observed decline in catalytic activity during the stability test [29]. It is further supported by the sharpening of the dominant CuO (111) peak at 38.74° post-reforming. Additionally, a weak diffraction peak emerges at 2θ = 50.45°, corresponding to the (200) plane of metallic Cu, confirming the partial reduction of CuO to Cu0 during pretreatment. However, subsequent air exposure after reforming leads to re-oxidation of most metallic Cu species. Figs. 12b-i presents the XPS spectra of the catalyst before reduction and after reforming. It can be seen from Fig. 12b that the catalyst does contain Cu, Zn, Al, O, and a small amount of C element detected in the survey spectrum is introduced for the sample preparation and calibration process [47]. Fig. 12c shows the Cu 2p spectrum of the catalyst. The Cu 2p3/2 peaks at 932.3 eV and 933.9 eV corresponds to Cu+ and Cu2+, respectively, with a weak satellite peak near 944 eV characteristic of Cu2+. The Cu 2p1/2 peaks at 951.2 eV and 953.7 eV aligns with the Cu 2p3/2 peaks [48]. Combined with XRD analysis, these results indicate that Cu2+ is the dominant species, with a minor presence of Cu+. As shown in the Zn 2p spectrum of Fig. 12d, the peaks at 1022.0 eV and 1045.0 eV correspond to Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2, respectively, with an energy separation of 23 eV, which is characteristic of Zn2+ bonded to O in the ZnO lattice [49]. In comparison, the Cu 2p and Zn 2p XPS spectra show minimal changes after the reforming reaction. A broad peak is evident in the O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 12e), which can be attributed to lattice oxygen (OL), adsorbed oxygen (OA), and water species (OW) upon deconvolution. Following the reforming reaction, the lattice oxygen (OL) peak in the XPS spectra (Fig. 12i) shows reduced intensity and lower content, which could explain the decline in catalytic activity observed in the stability test [50]. 4 Conclusion The adsorption characteristics of CH3OH and H2O on the surfaces of Cu-based catalysts are investigated using density functional theory (DFT), with findings validated through experimental verification. The adsorption behaviors of CH3OH at various sites on both Cu and Zn doped surfaces are specifically analyzed, along with the effects of H2O addition on adsorption characteristic. The main conclusions are as follows: (1) The adsorption of CH3OH on Cu surface is influenced by the different approaching atoms and adsorption sites. The adsorption energy is found to be the lowest when CH3OH approached the Cu surface by O atoms, accompanied by a significant charge transfer. Moreover, CH3OH exhibits lower adsorption energy and enhanced adsorption efficiency at the Top active site compared to the Bridge and Hollow sites. The PDOS plot for Model B-c indicates significant orbital hybridization between the O atom of CH3OH and the Cu atom on the adsorbed surface, resulting in the formation of stable covalent bonds. (2) The doping of Zn is found to enhance the adsorption of CH3OH on Cu surface. Mulliken charge reveals a consistent correlation between the charge transfer amount at adsorption site and adsorption energy. Moreover, the presence of H2O remarkably improves the adsorption of CH3OH on CuZn alloy surface, with this enhancement attributed to the synergistic adsorption of CH3OH by H2O and the adsorbed surface. However, it should be noted that elevated concentrations of H2O may lead to competition for adsorption, thereby inhibiting the adsorption reaction of CH3OH. (3) On pure Cu surfaces, methanol dehydrogenation is limited by the R2 step (CH3O → CH2O + H). Zn doping shifts the RDS to R1 (CH3OH → CH3O + H) by reducing the activation energies of both steps, while the presence of pre-adsorbed H2O further lowers the barrier for R1, reverting the RDS to R2. It demonstrates that H2O plays a critical role in promoting methanol dehydrogenation on Cu-based catalysts by facilitating the R1 step. (4) The hydrogen production from MSR reaction is found to exhibit considerably higher efficiency compared to that from DM reaction. Methanol conversion is observed to decrease with an increasing GHSV. Additionally, a tendency for methanol conversion to initially increase and then decrease is noted with the augmentation of the W/M, which can be partially attributed to the competitive adsorption of H2O with CH3OH. The decline in activity observed during the stability test can be attributed to catalyst sintering and the reduction of lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface. coredata.dc:description: The development of efficient hydrogen production technology from methanol holds significant importance for the green advancement of low-carbon marine engines. Cu-based catalysts, as the most widely used catalysts, face challenges such as facile sintering and carbon deposition, which significantly hinder the progress of hydrogen production through methanol reforming. Notably, the intricate interactions between Cu-based catalysts and CH3OH can be thoroughly analyzed at the microscopic level, providing an effective means to elucidate the pathways for catalyst modification. This work systematically investigates the adsorption characteristics of CH3OH on Cu surface grounded in density functional theory (DFT). By analyzing geometric parameters, Mulliken charges, density of states, and other relevant metrics, the bonding mechanisms and electronic arrangements among the constituent atoms are elucidated. The interaction between CH3OH and the Cu surface is investigated using molecular dynamics simulations, complemented by energy barrier analysis of the key steps in methanol dissociation. The simulation results are further validated through experimental studies on methanol reforming. The results reveal that CH3OH preferentially approaches Cu surface via O atom, confirming its tendency for adsorption at the Top site of Cu surface. Furthermore, the incorporation of Zn elements through doping, alongside an optimal concentration of H2O, significantly enhances the adsorption capacity for CH3OH and promotes the dissociation of methanol, thereby improving the overall efficiency of the reaction. The observed promoting effect of adding H2O aligns well with the experimental findings related to hydrogen production from methanol.
